Description: Body sherd (mended from two fragments) of Attic black-figured pottery band-cup; interior glazed black; exterior: lip glazed; in handle zone, black-figure decoration consisting of komos scene with two male figures and three female figures dancing; from left, woman's hand in added white, to right; upper part of nude male with added red hair and chest, looking to left; in the centre, nude white woman (legs missing) to right; part of nude male dancing with right leg kicked up behind him, to left; at right, white buttock and thigh of nude woman, to right.
Curator's comments: The sherd possibly belongs to the same vessel as British Museum 1965, 0930.763. British Museum 1965, 0930.762, 1965,0930.763, and 1965,0930.764 are the unnumbered fragments given by Beazley as belonging with 1888,0601.594.b, but these sherds come from a different cup or cups as they are thicker and have a different curvature (Beazley ABV, 250, no. 25).
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 400, no. B592)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 235, no. 2)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0483) (Phase 1)
